content.text: *OpenAI launches ChatGPT app platform with third-party integrations*

OpenAI announced at its DevDay on Monday that ChatGPT will host third-party apps inside the chat interface and released a new Apps SDK for developers. Early integrations include services such as Spotify, Zillow, and Booking.com, enabling users to create playlists or browse homes via natural-language prompts in ChatGPT. OpenAI said developers can submit apps for review later this year with monetization details to follow, and CEO Sam Altman cited 800 million weekly ChatGPT users alongside new commerce features for in‑chat purchases.
*Verizon names ex-PayPal chief Dan Schulman CEO*

Verizon named former PayPal chief and Verizon board member Dan Schulman as its new CEO, replacing Hans Vestberg. Fortune also reports that Oscar Health CEO Mark Bertolini was elected Verizon’s board chair, and that Vestberg will remain as a special advisor focused on integrating a $20 billion acquisition of Frontier Communications. The leadership shift comes as Verizon faces slowing subscriber growth and rising competition in wireless.
*Social Security chief Frank Bisignano named IRS CEO*

Treasury named Social Security Administration Commissioner Frank Bisignano to the newly created role of IRS chief executive officer, with responsibility for day-to-day operations, while he continues leading Social Security. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will remain the IRS commissioner after temporarily filling the role, maintaining a split structure between strategic oversight and daily management.
*Tata-owned Jaguar Land Rover restarts; UK offers £1.5bn support*

Jaguar Land Rover will begin a phased restart of manufacturing on Wednesday after a cyberattack on the last day of August forced it to halt factories and retail operations worldwide. To steady its supply chain, the company launched a scheme to give suppliers cash upfront during the restart, while the UK government provided a £1.5bn backstop to support affected suppliers. The measures are designed to ease suppliers’ cash crunch and help get customer deliveries back on track.
*France bond yields rise as third Macron premier quits*

On Monday, French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office, intensifying worries about France’s ability to address its large debt load. Investors reacted quickly: French bond yields jumped and stocks fell as uncertainty increased. It is the third premier President Emmanuel Macron has lost since his 2024 snap elections, and his choices now include appointing a new prime minister, calling new parliamentary elections, or resigning.
*Japan stocks surge, yen slides after LDP elects Takaichi*

Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party chose Sanae Takaichi as leader, prompting a market rally that sent Japanese stocks to record levels while the yen weakened. Investors are pricing in pro-growth, pro-stimulus moves, including more fiscal spending and pressure on the central bank to keep interest rates low. Analysts caution a full Abenomics-style revival may be constrained by inflation near 3% and a yen around 150 per dollar.
*US bank Fifth Third to acquire Comerica for $10.9B*

Fifth Third Bancorp said it will acquire Comerica in an all-stock transaction valued at $10.9 billion, announced Monday. The combined lender would rank ninth in the US with about $288 billion in assets and be described as the ninth-largest by other coverage.
*Tesla signals Oct. 7 announcement, affordable Model Y expected*

Tesla posted cryptic videos on X over the weekend that end with “10/7,” pointing to an announcement on Tuesday. Analysts expect a more affordable version of the best-selling Model Y aimed at reviving sales and defending market share amid rising competition. Shares rose about 5% after the tease, and the timing comes days after key U.S. EV tax credits expired, effectively raising prices by $7,500.
*US Supreme Court lets Android app store reforms proceed*

The US Supreme Court on Monday declined Google's request to pause parts of a lower-court order requiring reforms to its Android Play Store amid its antitrust dispute with Epic Games. The decision means changes aimed at loosening restrictions on app distribution and payments will move forward while appeals continue. Consumers and developers could benefit through more choice and potentially lower prices on downloads.
*CBS parent buys Free Press, names Bari Weiss editor-in-chief*

Paramount Skydance will acquire The Free Press and appoint its co-founder Bari Weiss as editor in chief of CBS News, marking a leadership shake-up at the broadcaster. The Los Angeles Times reported the deal price at $150 million in cash and stock. Weiss will report directly to Paramount CEO David Ellison, and the mandate was described as delivering "balanced and fact-based" news.
*Update: Senate stalemate extends sixth-day shutdown; Trump floats health talks*

In the latest development, the U.S. government shutdown entered its sixth day with no breakthrough in Congress, after Senate funding votes failed again and the House planned no votes this week. President Trump said he is open to negotiating with Democrats on health care subsidies — a potential opening for a deal — but indicated talks would follow reopening the government. Economists warned the shutdown is halting key federal economic data releases, adding uncertainty for businesses and markets.
*OpenAI signs AMD chip deal for 6GW, stake option*

OpenAI and AMD agreed to a multibillion-dollar partnership to deploy up to 6 gigawatts of AMD Instinct GPUs, with an initial 1-gigawatt rollout slated for 2026. The agreement includes an option for OpenAI to acquire up to roughly a 10% stake in AMD, and AMD shares rose more than 20% on the news. The move is part of OpenAI’s wider push to secure compute, with recent deals that together top about $1 trillion, including access to 10 gigawatts via Nvidia and a multiyear Oracle pact.
